1666830303648956416.text:
Replit AI Manifesto

This manifesto is the culmination of a conversation @amasad and I have had for over a year on the future of AI and its impact on the software industry.

I decided to join @Replit as VP of AI because I want to turn our shared vision into reality.

1/ üßµ https://t.co/9boL0wfhis

1666837226976870403.text:
A new meaning to REPL.

This novel feedback loop sits at the core of the Replit ADI. We call it the ‚ÄúReflect, Evaluate, Percolate and Learn‚Äù loop ‚Äì a whole new meaning to REPL. The agentic behavior of our ADI won‚Äôt be limited by what recent LLMs can do, but will rather keep‚Ä¶ https://t.co/Z8kXeNrAC1

1666837905703342080.text:
A new quote for the Replit yearbook.

Our company history, since 2016, is one of steady and tangible growth rather than of chasing the hype ‚Äì it‚Äôs deeply rooted in our culture. We can see the road ahead that will lead us to ADI, and we are paving the way for it ‚Äì line of code by‚Ä¶

1666836698263871488.text:
Building the Replit ADI is the most ambitious project we have ever undertaken. 

In spite of the meteoric rise of LLMs, we are deeply aware of the many challenges they still entail (for instance, hallucinations). Our focus on code, though, allows us to lift the LLM input/output‚Ä¶ https://t.co/x2mUZbHXnH

1666211786742435843.text:
RT @amasad: Thrilled to welcome @pirroh to the team at @Replit as VP of AI. 

This manifesto is a culmination of a year-long conversation w‚Ä¶

1663366478094270464.text:
When it comes to LLMs, it's easy to build products, but not easy to maintain them -- progress is so fast-paced that it's hard to predict if what works today will still be the best approach by end of year.
Still, In-Context Learning + Retrieval work great for now! Let's build üöÄ

1663366223491645440.text:
We already see a bimodal distribution:
üëâ "giant" LLMs keep improving, supporting as many use cases as possible, but trading off on $ and latency üëâ "specialized" LLMs have narrower scope, but better $ and latency

Equally useful. Matter of fact, Ghostwriter leverages both!

1663364701223550976.text:
It's getting easier by the day to fine tune LLMs! For example, QLora on a 65B LLM with a single 48GB GPU: https://t.co/a7UHsVAdJ9 

Training LLMs from scratch like we did at @Replit
is certainly more work, but companies like @MosaicML and @huggingface make it way more accessible.

1663363672826351616.text:
LLMs still struggle with program semantics, so I'm skeptical on their ability to predict program execution, aside of toy examples.
That said,  training on code + error traces made LLMs  an invaluable debugging tool -- Ghostwriter Chat  supports that!
üßµ 1/2

1663363880209481730.text:
As evidence, check this recent paper:
https://t.co/jzLMcbWhTh
üßµ 2/2

1663363319233929216.text:
The main challenge for LLM interoperability is the lack of a standardized "protocol" -- different LLMs require different prompting to achieve the best possible performance.
@LangChainAI built a great abstraction layer, but updating the prompts on new LLM releases is still on us!

1651440427793534977.text:
@sir_deenicus @abacaj ‚Ä¶ but some basic support for code explanation.

1651440781285285895.text: @sir_deenicus @abacaj That being said, we are releasing the model as open-source so we can get feedback from all of you, and do better next time!

1651430150314274818.text:

- MIM focuses mostly on 9 languages, while we included the 15+ top languages in Replit

1349237578596114432.text:
üî¶ (Highlight Of The Day) HOTD 01/12 - #CS224W Lecture 1

Graph Machine Learninng ‚Äî two sides of the same coin.
- why is it one of the most exciting research areas in ML? (the Good)
- why is it a hard technical problem? (the Bad)

1349237592382865408.text:
The Bad ‚Äî why Graph ML is hard?

The modern Deep Learning toolbox is designed for sequences and grids. Graphs lack the regular structure leveraged by models like RNNs and CNNs. As such, applying modern ML to graphs required a brand new paradigm ‚Äî Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). https://t.co/T4rozu3cg1

1349237593779494915.text:
Eager to learn more?
Check the slide deck from Lecture 1: https://t.co/FE8sP9KaKn

And stay tuned for new #CS224W highlights on Thu!

1348837702980890628.text: This quarter I‚Äôm advising 2 @Stanford courses: CS224W ‚ÄúML with Graphs‚Äù and CS329S ‚ÄúML Systems Design‚Äù (respectively taught by @jure and @chipro). To break my bad habit of being dormant on Twitter, I‚Äôll tweet some highlights after every lecture!

1349225851586371585.text: We plan to release a video series on YouTube for the whole CS224W course. Just allow us some time for editing and captioning ‚Äî I‚Äôll announce it on Twitter ASAP! /cc @SanjogMehta @gurdeepmaurya @ML_DL_eng @sAliAlavi

1348842944250273792.text:
6 myths of ML Systems in production:

1.  Deploying models (w/o SLAs) is hard
2. You only deploy a handful models at a time
3.  Model performance remains the same over time

#cs329s

1348842944975958017.text:
4.  You won‚Äôt need to redeploy your models as much
5.  Most ML engineers don‚Äôt need to worry about scale
6.  ML can magically transform your business overnight

#cs329s

1348844229129236484.text:
A great resource to debunk myth #3 is WILDS: a benchmark of in-the-wild distribution shifts spanning diverse data modalities and applications, from tumor identification to wildlife monitoring to poverty mapping.

https://t.co/YxrLCLg9nq

1004081515712602112.text: @MasterScrat Exactly! And it wouldn't be that hard -- as an example: "[...] We assume we can identify an author's gender if the author's first name is associated with a single gender in social security records at least 95% of the time. [...]" https://t.co/rFZVodPkhw

1003704994913112064.text: This is a common high risk / low return scenario in data science: misclassifications are glaring, but the mail would have been routed even w/o the useless gendered title!

At Replit, our mission is to empower the next billion software creators. 

Our users build software collaboratively with the power of AI, on any device, without spending a second on setup. We accomplished that by creating from the ground up a delightful developer experience.
The‚Ä¶ https://t.co/RS7uByPEwJ

1653587019657015298.text:
This is the base model, and while it‚Äôs very powerful for its size, there is still more power to be gotten out of it with finetuning.
At Replit we got ~50% performance boost üí™
We look forward to seeing what you do with it!
4/

1666833589185699841.text:
Towards an Artificial Developer Intelligence.

At Replit, we are rethinking from the ground up the developer experience, with AI as a first-class citizen of the development environment. To this end, we have been working daily to build an ADI ‚Äì Artificial Developer Intelligence.‚Ä¶

A recipe for Human-Computer symbiosis.

When it comes to software development, this recipe has paid off successfully for many years. Programming languages and frameworks have been gradually abstracted away from the hardware, by means of designing more expressive abstractions and‚Ä¶ https://t.co/mtGauOTAjt

AI is changing the game for software development. 

Large Language Models (LLMs) can now write substantial portions of code, provide assistance with debugging, explain functions step-by-step, and recommend system design ‚Äì all features you can already experience today on Replit‚Ä¶
